ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Also virtual lab
In addition to the biweekly seminars, this course also involved a writing lab/ collections visiting period each week.
Friday labs
Virtual Seminar, TF Breakout Rooms, Virtual Visits to the Beinecke.
This class had a unique lecture/ discussion combined format.
Both virtual seminar and virtual lab.
We had weekly "labs" where the professors or guests talked about different Yale collections.
also consisted of virtual labs on fridays
In addition to the virtual seminar that took place twice per week, this class also included a virtual lab every Friday.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A LOT
I improved at close-reading and feel much more prepared for college writing.

This course helped me significantly improve my writing abilities and confidence.  The readings and discussions also opened my mind to new ways of thinking about formation and manifestations of the self in different cultural and temporal contexts. I also improved my ability to participate in active discussion of readings and films through this class.

I learned so much more than I could have bargained for. From learning how to write emails, form theses, structure academic papers, explore Yales vast resources, connect with tutors, and build relationships with professors, TFs + peers in a virtual setting, this class did this AND more. I was able to read the classics, explore texts close to my identity, all while feeling confident and supported.

I learned a great deal about Yale's collections, the idea of a collection, close reading, comparing texts, and technical and stylistic aspects of writing. This course also expanded my approach to texts from just looking at what they say (or what someone says they say) to what they do/what they are/where they come from/why they matter.
Close reading/analysis of a text, improving my writing process, and learning about Yale resources.
I improved my college writing immensely, honed discussion skills, learned how to utilize some of Yale's incredible resources including the library and collections.
I learned a good amount about the writing process and new ways to think about writing. I also developed an appreciation for literary traditions I had never been exposed to.
I learned how to read texts critically, write an essay and grow comfortable with my writing process, and think about abstract concepts like selfhood.

I was able to develop my writing skills as a whole. I learned how to get more out of the text that I was presented, and then with that extra information I was able to apply it to my writing more efficiently.

This class really improved my writing process and introduced me to works of literature and film from all around the world. It also made me feel a lot more comfortable with using Yale resources, especially in terms of research.

Through this course, I developed college-level writing skills. I also became a better reader, and more able to understand difficult or dense texts. The course material itself was fascinating, and I gained a lot of insight into how I view myself and how that view is influenced by my environment. I was exposed to texts from all different locations, cultures, and time periods, so I felt I developed a good understanding of how views on the self vary across the world and throughout time.

i learned everything about developing a proper writing process to thinking differently and critically about complex readings. i pushed myself as a writer in ways i had been afraid to before this class. the positive impact of this course on me has been immeasurable.

I learned how to close read, to write, and to analyze text. My writing and reading skills improved. More importantly, I think, I learned about perspective. This class really opened up my thoughts to other perspectives and opinions by hearing my classmates and their insights about the texts and films featured in the syllabus. I also learned about writing as a process and not simply as a one-time, one-sitting task. Writing, as a process, was challenging for me, but I know now what I can do to help myself become a better writer. I also learned more about myself as a communicator and an individual with my own thoughts, morals, and values.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: All strengths. No weaknesses. Please continue to fund Humanities courses such as these because I think I speak for my entire class when I say that this is truly one of the best courses I've ever had in my life.

This was a really wonderful course. I really appreciated the variety and interest of the reading and film material for the class. The discussion was also very interesting and engaging, especially when the professors entered the breakout rooms. The collections visits were also very interesting, especially after the changes made after the midterm. Most of the weaknesses I saw in the course (lack of engagement in collections visits and not enough time spent in breakout rooms) were addressed after the midterm review.

Strengths: I appreciated the feedback from TFs and seminar style discussions

Weaknesses: Felt there wasnt enough time to go over all texts. Friday lab times could have been used more productivelyat times the Beinecke talks got a bit too long but Im sure this was just due to the virtual nature of the sessions

I thought the format of the course was great, and even without being physically there, collections days were so interesting! This course also used a huge variety of material both in terms of time and place of origin and in terms of genre, which was really exciting and eye-opening. However, there were no older texts from the Americas, and none from the Pacific at all, which is not inherently bad, but it definitely would have been interesting to contrast the older texts from Europe and Asia against similar self-making narratives from pre-colonial societies.

Strengths: Great professors and TFs, interesting material, well organized, and awesome discussion!
Weaknesses: The common thread of selfhood wasn't always entirely obvious, but this didn't reduce the quality of conversation at all.

I don't really have anything bad to say about this class. I looked forward to attending lectures and doing assignments every day. We read widely and deeply across many literary and philosophical traditions.
I very much enjoyed the wide range of topics and works covered, but at times discussion felt somewhat unstructured with ambiguous takeaways.

The strengths include the professors' teaching styles, the intersectional, international structure of the syllabus, and the structure of the course in general. A way in which this course might be improved is by allowing more discussion time (whether in a group discussion or in writing) for deeper analysis of specific works (like reading responses pertinent to specific texts).

incredibly insightful discussions everyday, and very interesting friday labs switching from visits to yale collections and writing workshops. i think this aspect of the class was so valuable to the experience as a whole. overall, the TFs and Profs were able to very successfully conduct class, remote as we were. i would do it over again in a heartbeat!

I think one of the weaknesses was the online lab period. I just feel like it was not as engaging as I would have liked it to be. Most of the material was interesting; however, because it was not really engaging, it was hard to concentrate. I think this online lab can be improved through using tools that Zoom has to offer such as breakout rooms or using other tools from external sources to engage the class. This class felt overwhelming at first because I did not come into the class knowing how to coherently communicate my ideas at the same level of expertise as my peers. I think this made the seminar sessions intimidating when it came to addressing my ideas. However, I consider this a strength for me personally because it challenged me and provided a way for me to learn from my classmates. After thinking about the seminar as more of a learning opportunity and less of a display of intelligence, the environment became a kind of safe space to openly share my thoughts and feelings regarding the material. The professors and TAs truly did a wonderful job of ensuring this environment was preserved throughout the semester.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Breakout rooms within a virtual seminar setting worked well. I don't think this class could be improved in how my professors and TFs navigated through remote learning, everything went as smoothly and efficiently as it could.

The breakout rooms were very helpful in encouraging virtual engagement. Xavier Lee, the teaching fellow who led my breakout room discussions, did a really good job of encouraging discussion and challenging us to discuss difficult topics. I also really appreciated when the professors joined us in our discussions.
Improved: Friday labs

The use of breakout rooms was really engaging, and I loved having the Discord to communicate on. Friday classes (especially writing labs) could sometimes feel a bit long on Zoom, but they improved over the course of the semester.
Everything went pretty well! This course will be even more fun when students are able to join the professors and TFs in Yale collections and explore those resources.
The virtual lecture/ discussions were vivid and engaging. I especially appreciated the professor's planning in-person meet-ups throughout the semester to foster bonding.

The discussion seminars in this course were held over zoom, and these were a great success. Though we were over zoom, I felt that the small-group setting and the use of breakout rooms allowed for comfortable participation and fruitful discussion with the time that was available. Though they seemed very long at the beginning of the semester, the virtual Friday labs were very interesting, informative, and helpful in beginning to navigate resources at Yale. In my experience this past semester, the Friday writing labs of this course were some of the most engaging and productive virtual learning experiences I had. This time was helpful not only in vastly improving my writing skills but also in discussing writing with peers and meeting other students.
The use of breakout rooms and Zoom chat was very effective and made the class very engaging despite the pandemic.
during our zoom discussions, i felt so engaged that i couldnt imagine being in person for the same discussion would feel significantly different. very great experience overall.

I think that "raising hands" through Zoom worked well for the seminar environment. I also think that the organization of the seminars with the TAs having designated roles and the professors mainly leading the main group discussions worked well. The breakout rooms during every seminar session was a success. I just think that the only practice that could be improved is the online lab.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would 100% recommend it. This course is engaging in coursework and in discussion, it has a clearly defined structure, and it fulfills its goal of examining the six selves across literature and film throughout most of human history.
I would recommend this course, the professors are amazing and so funny!

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student! The professors and teaching fellows are amazing, the text and film materials are wonderful in their interest and variety, and the class as a whole is a really engaging experience.

Absolutely. You'll be met with incredible TFs and professors who are genuinely excited to teach the material. Youll learn so much from the logistics of writing to close reading texts and getting accustomed to a variety of them.
Yes!!! This course changed the way I think and also made me much more confident about using Yale's resources.
Absolutely! A great freshman seminar with professors and TFs that care and a helpful, tiered approach to college writing.
Yes, without question. Take this class, or any classes taught by Professors Ramachandran and Figlerowicz.

This course was a very broad introduction to the humanities, so if that is your thing you will probably really enjoy it. Definitely check the reading list and see if most of the readings pique your interests.

I would absolutely recommend this class to other students, and especially to other first-years. The professors are incredibly kind, engaging, and helpful, and the class is directed in a manner that prioritizes academic growth. The subject matter might seem dauntingly abstract at first glance, but is helpfully discussed, contextualized, and explained by professors and TFs. I grew a lot during this course, and though it was certainly challenging, I never felt stranded because professors and TFs alike were incredibly responsive and open to answering questions at all points in the course. On top of this, this class is also a great introduction to academic writing and to resources at Yale. This is a phenomenal course.
Yes, it is an interesting course that can provide a different perspective on the topic of self.

I would definitely recommend this class to other students. It was probably my best experience with school in a pandemic setting. The professors are both awesome and were super understanding of the circumstances, the TFs were super approachable and helpful, and the content was really engaging.

I would recommend this course to another student! I thought that the course material was sometimes hard to grasp and especially hard to write about, but I improved greatly over the course of the semester. You get out what you put in in that regard I think. The professors and TFs were all amazing and supportive, and the class community was wonderful. The professors also presented us with quite a few careers in the humanities which were very interesting to learn about and I felt like it gave me options looking to my own future. The syllabus is a big part of what makes this class so great in my opinion. We read everything from plays to philosophical texts to novels. We even watched movies for some classes, ranging from The Human Condition to a Bollywood musical. I loved being exposed to all kinds of different works and ideas. The discussion parts of this class were also great. Sometimes the collections labs could stretch on (a three hour Zoom call is a lot), but that's the only structural complaint I ever had about this course. Take this course! I'm a much better writer because of this experience, and it's really rewarding.

absolutely. for all the reasons i listed above, and just how transformative it was for me, i would recommend this to any student, regardless of their major path. everyone can stand to learn and talk about the concepts and issues we looked into in 6PGS

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. The professors and TAs were amazing. The texts and films assigned were both challenging and enjoyable. The basics of writing and reading taught are essential and very important for future writing. The individual development was very helpful for me and for my experience at Yale as a first-year.
